metadata.title: Best Practices - CDK for Terraform
metadata.description: Build robust applications for production use cases. How to manage secrets, build constructs, design stacks, and more.

mdxSource.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={};const MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components,...props}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...props,components:components,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`There are many ways to structure your CDK for Terraform (CDKTF) application. The structure you choose depends largely on the best practices for your chosen programming language and your use case. However, we recommend using the following principles to build robust, production-ready applications.`),mdx("h2",{"id":"read-secrets-with-terraform-variables"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h2","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#read-secrets-with-terraform-variables","aria-label":"read secrets with terraform variables permalink"},`\xbb`),`Read Secrets with Terraform Variables`),mdx("p",null,`Secrets appear in your synthesized CDKTF code when you read them directly from environment variables or from files with normal system access. This introduces risk, especially if you are checking the synthesized configuration into a version control system. To mitigate this, `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cdktf/concepts/variables-and-outputs#input-variables"},`use the `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"a"},`TerraformVariable`),` construct`),` to read secrets. Terraform uses the values in `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`TerraformVariable`),` directly at execution time, so CDKTF does not write them to the synthesized `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`cdktf.json`),` file.`),mdx("p",null,`The following example uses a Terraform variable to read the sensitive admin password instead of reading it directly from an environment variable.`),mdx("pre",{"className":"language-typescript"},mdx("code",{parentName:"pre","className":"language-typescript"},mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`const`),` adminPassword `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token operator"},`=`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`new`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token class-name"},mdx("span",{parentName:"span","className":"token maybe-class-name"},`TerraformVariable`)),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`(`),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`this`),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`,`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token string"},`"adminPassword"`),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`,`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`{`),`

`)),mdx("p",null,`To pass a `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cli/config/environment-variables#tf_var_name"},`Terraform variable through environment variables`),`, name the environment variable `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`TF_VAR_NAME`),`. For example, set `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`TF_VAR_adminPassword='<your password>'`),` in the execution environment.`),mdx("p",null,`If you use HCP Terraform with `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cloud-docs/run/remote-operations#remote-operations"},`remote execution`),`, you can store your secrets in HCP Terraform. Refer to the HCP Terraform documentation about `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cloud-docs/workspaces/variables/managing-variables#workspace-specific-variables"},`workspace variables`),` for more details.`),mdx("p",null,`We recommend using `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`TerraformVariable`),` only at the Stack level. Nesting them in custom constructs makes the interface unclear because some information may be passed into the constructor of the construct, while other data may be passed through a `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`TerraformVariable`),`. Nesting also changes the logical ID and makes it difficult to understand which `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`TerraformVariable`),` instances you must configure for the CDKTF program to run.`),mdx("h2",{"id":"providers"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h2","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#providers","aria-label":"providers permalink"},`\xbb`),`Providers`),mdx("p",null,`A provider is a Terraform plugin that allows users to manage an external API. Provider plugins act as a translation layer that allows Terraform to communicate with many different cloud providers, databases, and services.`),mdx("p",null,`Use `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cdktf/concepts/providers#install-pre-built-providers"},`pre-built providers`),` when possible. It can take several minutes to generate the code bindings for providers with very large schemas, so we offer several popular providers as pre-built packages. Pre-built providers are a performance optimization that reduces the time it takes to synthesize and run your application. You can also use pre-built providers as a peer dependency if you use open-source custom constructs.`),mdx("p",null,`Refer to the `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"https://github.com/orgs/cdktf/repositories?q=cdktf-provider-"},`CDKTF Provider GitHub repositories`),` for a complete list of pre-built providers.`),mdx("h2",{"id":"application-architecture"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h2","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#application-architecture","aria-label":"application architecture permalink"},`\xbb`),`Application Architecture`),mdx("p",null,`We recommend the following best practices when structuring your CDKTF application.`),mdx("h3",{"id":"separate-business-units-with-stacks"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#separate-business-units-with-stacks","aria-label":"separate business units with stacks permalink"},`\xbb`),`Separate Business Units with Stacks`),mdx("p",null,`A `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/terraform/cdktf/concepts/stacks"},`stack`),` represents a collection of infrastructure that CDKTF synthesizes as a dedicated Terraform configuration. Stacks allow you to separate the state management for multiple environments within an application. We recommend creating separate stacks for the following use cases:`),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},`Deployment stages (development / staging / production)`),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},`Business purposes (e-commerce / blog / data warehouse)`),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},`Regions (eu-west-1 / us-east-1) if they deploy similar infrastructure, e.g. for high availability`),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},`Software components (network / db / compute)`),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},`Deployment cycles (databases and domain names / applications)`)),mdx("p",null,`You do not always need to create a new class for each stack. For some use cases, it is more efficient to create a single stack class to define similar infrastructure and then pass arguments into the stack that customize the deployment. For example, you might create a class that creates AWS EC2 instances and then pass different regions and other configuration details based on the team or production stage that requires the infrastructure.`),mdx("p",null,`The following example customizes the same base stack for different business purposes and staging environments.`),mdx("pre",{"className":"language-typescript"},mdx("code",{parentName:"pre","className":"language-typescript"},mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`const`),` devNetworking `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token operator"},`=`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`new`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token class-name"},mdx("span",{parentName:"span","className":"token maybe-class-name"},`NetworkingStack`)),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`(`),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token keyword"},`this`),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`,`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token string"},`"networking-development"`),mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`,`),` `,mdx("span",{parentName:"code","className":"token punctuation"},`{`),`
